etymologies: Middle English: a reduced form of the obsolete conjunction other (which superseded Old English oththe ‘or’), of uncertain ultimate origin

notes.text: Where a verb follows a list separated by or, the traditional rule is that the verb should be singular, as long as the things in the list are individually singular, as in a sandwich or other snack is included in the price (rather than a sandwich or other snack are included in the price). The argument is that each of the elements agrees separately with the verb. The opposite rule applies when the elements are joined by and—here the verb should be plural: a sandwich and a cup of coffee are included in the price. These traditional rules are observed in good English writing style but are often disregarded in speech. On the use of either … or, see either

examples.text: a cup of tea or coffee
I either take taxis or walk everywhere
it doesn't matter whether the theory is right or wrong

definitions: introducing a synonym or explanation of a preceding word or phrase

examples.text: the espionage novel, or, as it is known in the trade, the thriller

definitions: otherwise (used to introduce the consequences of something not being done or not being the case)

examples.text: hurry up, or you'll miss it all

definitions: introducing an afterthought, usually in the form of a question

examples.text: John's indifference—or was it?—left her unsettled
to love is the one way to know or God or man

notes.text: Where a verb follows a list separated by or, the traditional rule is that the verb should be singular, as long as the things in the list are individually singular, as in a sandwich or other snack is included in the price (rather than a sandwich or other snack are included in the price). The argument is that each of the elements agrees separately with the verb. The opposite rule applies when the elements are joined by and—here the verb should be plural: a sandwich and a cup of coffee are included in the price. These traditional rules are observed in good English writing style but are often disregarded in speech. On the use of either … or, see either

definitions: a Boolean operator that gives the value one if at least one operand (or input) has a value of one, and otherwise has a value of zero.
shortDefinitions: logical operation which gives value one if at least one operand has value one

definitions: a circuit that gives an output signal if there is a signal on any of its inputs.
shortDefinitions: denoting gate circuit which produces output if there is signal on any of its inputs

etymologies: early 16th century: from French, from Latin aurum ‘gold’

definitions: gold or yellow, as a heraldic tincture
shortDefinitions: gold or yellow, as heraldic tincture
